Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I had just finished a long morning at the pharmacy, my mind still buzzing with the new prescription guidelines I’d learned at the workshop. I was determined to apply them, knowing how much my patients relied on me for accurate advice. But today was also Election Day, and I hurried to the polling station, wanting to fulfill my civic duty. As I sealed my ballot envelope, the poll worker noticed a smudge and asked me to re-sign it. I hesitated. The workshop had drilled into me the importance of signatures on medical documents—how even a small discrepancy could cause legal trouble or invalidate a prescription. Now, as a voter, I was being told to sign again, but I worried: would two signatures on the envelope cause my ballot to be rejected? The poll worker insisted it was standard procedure, but my pharmacist’s training screamed caution. I felt torn, caught between my professional instinct to avoid signature errors and my responsibility to follow the poll worker’s instructions. My heart pounded as I stared at the envelope, unsure which role’s expectations I should honor.
